awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: Volatility Shocks, Financial Frictions, and Labor Force Reallocation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

While it has been acknowledged that volatility shocks (increasing uncertainty) can raise firms’ bankruptcy risks and generate recessions, general assumption is that labor force is perfectly insured from these bankruptcies. This assumption deviates from the notion that labor force is averse to financially distressed firms. This project will focus on this aspect by considering that labor force is aware of firms’ bankruptcy risks and require higher wages to compensate for expected losses. Within this framework, a positive volatility shock amplifies the compensating wage differentials across firms with different leverage, driving labor force reallocation from highly leveraged firms to less leveraged firms. This project will develop a model and using data on labor force; the research will test the hypothesized effect of volatility shocks on labor force reallocation. The project will explore the corresponding welfare implications, which will have potential labor market policy implications.

This research will use employer-employee matched data to show new empirical facts of how the relationship between volatility and labor market outcomes depends on firms’ financial conditions. The project will build on the hypothesis that higher volatility increases firms’ bankruptcy risks. Labor force is averse to firms’ bankruptcy risks. Thus, it is harder for highly leveraged firms to hire workforce, which will affect labor wages and employment. Labor force will reallocate to less leverage firms, implying the allocation of labor force across firms deviates from the optimal level. The mechanism considered in the project will be useful in explaining why the labor market was adversely affected during the financial crisis. The employer-employee matched data will be helpful in controlling the characteristics of firms and workforce. The project will explore the role of compensating wage differentials within the context of firms’ financial conditions. The research will further shed light on the role of firm heterogeneity over business cycles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Unemployment rates notably rise during recessions, accompanied by an increase in uncertainty faced by firms. This project investigates the extent to which heightened uncertainty in firm-level idiosyncratic productivity contributes to increased unemployment. Prior research within the canonical search framework has limited the explanatory power of uncertainty shocks on unemployment (Schaal, 2017). However, our study revisits this impact and discovers that when financial and labor contracting frictions are present, uncertainty shocks play a crucial role in accounting for the rise in unemployment during recessions.

 

Our approach develops in two phases. First, using U.S. Census employer-employee matched data, we observe that financially constrained firms tend to lay off workers more during periods of elevated uncertainty. This finding deviates from the expected real option channel in standard search models, which typically suggest a freeze in layoffs due to the increased option value of waiting in times of uncertainty. This inconsistency led us to develop a new search model, integrating financial and labor contracting frictions. These frictions create a risk premium channel: each worker represents a wage commitment, and firms are hesitant to undertake these commitments when increased uncertainty amplifies bankruptcy risks. This mechanism aligns layoff behaviors with empirical observations, explaining over 70% of the impact of uncertainty on unemployment and significantly enhancing the model’s ability to mirror real-world unemployment dynamics during economic downturns.

 

Furthermore, our general equilibrium quantitative model evaluates two contrasting labor market stabilization strategies during periods of high uncertainty: enhancing unemployment benefits for workers versus offering wage subsidies to firms. The model assesses the U.S. policy of increased unemployment benefits during the Covid recession, revealing that although it aims to support unemployed workers, it inadvertently increases wages, thereby escalating hiring risks for firms and potentially exacerbating unemployment. Conversely, the model investigates the efficacy of wage subsidy policies, similar to those implemented by Germany during the Great Recession and the Covid recession. These subsidies cushion firms against idiosyncratic shocks, mitigating the negative impact of heightened uncertainty. Nonetheless, the model also highlights a caveat: while wage subsidies can reduce unemployment more effectively than increased unemployment benefits, they may encourage labor hoarding and impede efficient worker reallocation, ultimately leading to efficiency losses due to misallocation.
